ospf.name: ospf

revisions.description: Updated for latest changes to OSPF Version 2: - updated the General Group with the new ospfRFC1583Compatibility, ospfReferenceBandwidth and ospfDiscontinuityTime objects - added graceful-restart-related objects - added stub-router-related objects - updated the Area Table with NSSA-related objects - added ospfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag object - added Opaque LSA-related objects - updates to the Compliances and Security sections - added area LSA counter table - added section describing translation of notification parameters between SNMP versions - added ospfComplianceObsolete to contain obsolete object groups - deprecated ospfExtLsdbTable See Appendix B of RFC 4750 for more details. This version published as part of RFC 4750
The initial SMIv2 revision of this MIB module, published in RFC 1850.

ospf.contactinfo: WG E-Mail: ospf@ietf.org WG Chairs: acee@cisco.com rohit@gmail.com Editors: Dan Joyal Nortel 600 Technology Park Drive Billerica, MA 01821 djoyal@nortel.com Piotr Galecki Airvana 19 Alpha Road Chelmsford, MA 01824 pgalecki@airvana.com Spencer Giacalone CSFB Eleven Madison Ave New York, NY 10010-3629 spencer.giacalone@gmail.com
ospf.description: The MIB module to describe the OSPF Version 2 Protocol. Note that some objects in this MIB module may pose a significant security risk. Refer to the Security Considerations section in RFC 4750 for more information. Copyright (C) The IETF Trust (2006). This version of this MIB module is part of RFC 4750; see the RFC itself for full legal notices.

AreaID.name: AreaID
AreaID.description: An OSPF Area Identifier. Note that the Area ID, in OSPF, has the same format as an IP address, but has the function of defining a summarization point for link state advertisements.

RouterID.name: RouterID
RouterID.description: A OSPF Router Identifier. Note that the Router ID, in OSPF, has the same format as an IP address, but identifies the router independent of its IP address.

Metric.name: Metric
Metric.description: The OSPF internal metric. Note that the OSPF metric is defined as an unsigned value in the range.

Status.name: Status
Status.description: An indication of the operability of an OSPF function or feature. For example, the status of an interface: 'enabled' indicates that it is willing to communicate with other OSPF routers, and 'disabled' indicates that it is not.

PositiveInteger.name: PositiveInteger
PositiveInteger.description: A positive integer. Values in excess are precluded as unnecessary and prone to interoperability issues.

HelloRange.name: HelloRange
HelloRange.description: The range of intervals in seconds on which Hello messages are exchanged.

UpToMaxAge.name: UpToMaxAge
UpToMaxAge.description: The values in seconds that one might find or configure for variables bounded by the maximum age of an LSA.

DesignatedRouterPriority.name: DesignatedRouterPriority
DesignatedRouterPriority.description: The range of values defined for the priority of a system for becoming the designated router.

TOSType.name: TOSType
TOSType.description: Type of Service (TOS) is defined as a mapping to the IP Type of Service Flags as defined in the IP Forwarding Table MIB +-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+ | | | | | PRECEDENCE | TYPE OF SERVICE | 0 | | | | | +-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+ IP TOS IP TOS Field Policy Field Policy Contents Code Contents Code 0 0 0 0 ==> 0 0 0 0 1 ==> 2 0 0 1 0 ==> 4 0 0 1 1 ==> 6 0 1 0 0 ==> 8 0 1 0 1 ==> 10 0 1 1 0 ==> 12 0 1 1 1 ==> 14 1 0 0 0 ==> 16 1 0 0 1 ==> 18 1 0 1 0 ==> 20 1 0 1 1 ==> 22 1 1 0 0 ==> 24 1 1 0 1 ==> 26 1 1 1 0 ==> 28 1 1 1 1 ==> 30 The remaining values are left for future definition.

ospfRouterId.name: ospfRouterId
ospfRouterId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the router in the Autonomous System. By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this should default to the value of one of the router's IP interface addresses. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfAdminStat.name: ospfAdminStat
ospfAdminStat.description: The administrative status of OSPF in the router. The value 'enabled' denotes that the OSPF Process is active on at least one interface; 'disabled' disables it on all interfaces. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfVersionNumber.name: ospfVersionNumber
ospfVersionNumber.description: The current version number of the OSPF protocol is 2.

ospfAreaBdrRtrStatus.name: ospfAreaBdrRtrStatus
ospfAreaBdrRtrStatus.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 3 Splitting the AS into Areas
ospfAreaBdrRtrStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is an Area Border Router.

ospfASBdrRtrStatus.name: ospfASBdrRtrStatus
ospfASBdrRtrStatus.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 3.3 Classification of routers
ospfASBdrRtrStatus.description: A flag to note whether this router is configured as an Autonomous System Border Router. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfExternLsaCount.name: ospfExternLsaCount
ospfExternLsaCount.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.5 AS external link advertisements
ospfExternLsaCount.description: The number of external (LS type-5) link state advertisements in the link state database.

ospfExternLsaCksumSum.name: ospfExternLsaCksumSum
ospfExternLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit sum of the LS checksums of the external link state advertisements contained in the link state database. This sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's link state database and to compare the link state database of two routers. The value should be treated as unsigned when comparing two sums of checksums.

ospfTOSSupport.name: ospfTOSSupport
ospfTOSSupport.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix F.1.2 Optional TOS support
ospfTOSSupport.description: The router's support for type-of-service routing. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfOriginateNewLsas.name: ospfOriginateNewLsas
ospfOriginateNewLsas.description: The number of new link state advertisements that have been originated. This number is incremented each time the router originates a new LSA. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfRxNewLsas.name: ospfRxNewLsas
ospfRxNewLsas.description: The number of link state advertisements received that are determined to be new instantiations. This number does not include newer instantiations of self-originated link state advertisements. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfExtLsdbLimit.name: ospfExtLsdbLimit
ospfExtLsdbLimit.description: The maximum number of non-default AS-external LSAs entries that can be stored in the link state database. If the value is -1, then there is no limit. When the number of non-default AS-external LSAs in a router's link state database reaches ospfExtLsdbLimit, the router enters overflow state. The router never holds more than ospfExtLsdbLimit non-default AS-external LSAs in its database. OspfExtLsdbLimit MUST be set identically in all routers attached to the OSPF backbone and/or any regular OSPF area (i.e., OSPF stub areas and NSSAs are excluded). This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfMulticastExtensions.name: ospfMulticastExtensions
ospfMulticastExtensions.description: A bit mask indicating whether the router is forwarding IP multicast (Class D) datagrams based on the algorithms defined in the multicast extensions to OSPF. Bit 0, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams in the router's directly attached areas (called intra-area multicast routing). Bit 1, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams between OSPF areas (called inter-area multicast routing). Bit 2, if set, indicates that the router can forward IP multicast datagrams between Autonomous Systems (called inter-AS multicast routing). Only certain combinations of bit settings are allowed, namely: 0 (no multicast forwarding is enabled), 1 (intra-area multicasting only), 3 (intra-area and inter-area multicasting), 5 (intra-area and inter-AS multicasting), and 7 (multicasting everywhere). By default, no multicast forwarding is enabled. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfExitOverflowInterval.name: ospfExitOverflowInterval
ospfExitOverflowInterval.description: The number of seconds that, after entering OverflowState, a router will attempt to leave OverflowState. This allows the router to again originate non-default AS-external LSAs. When set to 0, the router will not leave overflow state until restarted. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfDemandExtensions.name: ospfDemandExtensions
ospfDemandExtensions.reference: Extending OSPF to Support Demand Circuits
ospfDemandExtensions.description: The router's support for demand routing. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfRFC1583Compatibility.name: ospfRFC1583Compatibility
ospfRFC1583Compatibility.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 16.4.1 External path preferences
ospfRFC1583Compatibility.description: Indicates metrics used to choose among multiple AS-external LSAs. When RFC1583Compatibility is set to enabled, only cost will be used when choosing among multiple AS-external LSAs advertising the same destination. When RFC1583Compatibility is set to disabled, preference will be driven first by type of path using cost only to break ties. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfOpaqueLsaSupport.name: ospfOpaqueLsaSupport
ospfOpaqueLsaSupport.description: The router's support for Opaque LSA types.

ospfReferenceBandwidth.name: ospfReferenceBandwidth
ospfReferenceBandwidth.description: Reference bandwidth in kilobits/second for calculating default interface metrics. The default value is 100,000 KBPS (100 MBPS). This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfRestartSupport.name: ospfRestartSupport
ospfRestartSupport.description: The router's support for OSPF graceful restart. Options include: no restart support, only planned restarts, or both planned and unplanned restarts. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfRestartInterval.name: ospfRestartInterval
ospfRestartInterval.description: Configured OSPF graceful restart timeout interval. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfRestartStrictLsaChecking.name: ospfRestartStrictLsaChecking
ospfRestartStrictLsaChecking.description: Indicates if strict LSA checking is enabled for graceful restart. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfRestartStatus.name: ospfRestartStatus
ospfRestartStatus.description: Current status of OSPF graceful restart.

ospfRestartAge.name: ospfRestartAge
ospfRestartAge.description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart interval.

ospfRestartExitReason.name: ospfRestartExitReason
ospfRestartExitReason.description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at a graceful restart. If the value is 'none', no restart has yet been attempted. If the value is 'inProgress', a restart attempt is currently underway.

ospfAsLsaCount.name: ospfAsLsaCount
ospfAsLsaCount.description: The number of AS-scope link state advertisements in the AS-scope link state database.

ospfAsLsaCksumSum.name: ospfAsLsaCksumSum
ospfAsLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the LS checksums of the AS link state advertisements contained in the AS-scope link state database. This sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's AS-scope link state database, and to compare the AS-scope link state database of two routers.

ospfStubRouterSupport.name: ospfStubRouterSupport
ospfStubRouterSupport.description: The router's support for stub router functionality.

ospfStubRouterAdvertisement.name: ospfStubRouterAdvertisement
ospfStubRouterAdvertisement.description: This object controls the advertisement of stub router LSAs by the router. The value doNotAdvertise will result in the advertisement of a standard router LSA and is the default value. This object is persistent and when written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfDiscontinuityTime.name: ospfDiscontinuityTime
ospfDiscontinuityTime.description: The value of sysUpTime on the most recent occasion at which any one of this MIB's counters suffered a discontinuity. If no such discontinuities have occurred since the last re-initialization of the local management subsystem, then this object contains a zero value.

ospfAreaTable.name: ospfAreaTable
ospfAreaTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 6 The Area Data Structure
ospfAreaTable.description: Information describing the configured parameters and cumulative statistics of the router's attached areas. The interfaces and virtual links are configured as part of these areas. Area 0.0.0.0, by definition, is the backbone area.

ospfAreaEntry.name: ospfAreaEntry
ospfAreaEntry.description: Information describing the configured parameters and cumulative statistics of one of the router's attached areas. The interfaces and virtual links are configured as part of these areas. Area 0.0.0.0, by definition, is the backbone area. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfAreaId.name: ospfAreaId
ospfAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an area. Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.

ospfAuthType.name: ospfAuthType
ospfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for an area.

ospfImportAsExtern.name: ospfImportAsExtern
ospfImportAsExtern.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfImportAsExtern.description: Indicates if an area is a stub area, NSSA, or standard area. Type-5 AS-external LSAs and type-11 Opaque LSAs are not imported into stub areas or NSSAs. NSSAs import AS-external data as type-7 LSAs

ospfSpfRuns.name: ospfSpfRuns
ospfSpfRuns.description: The number of times that the intra-area route table has been calculated using this area's link state database. This is typically done using Dijkstra's algorithm. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfAreaBdrRtrCount.name: ospfAreaBdrRtrCount
ospfAreaBdrRtrCount.description: The total number of Area Border Routers reachable within this area. This is initially zero and is calculated in each Shortest Path First (SPF) pass.

ospfAsBdrRtrCount.name: ospfAsBdrRtrCount
ospfAsBdrRtrCount.description: The total number of Autonomous System Border Routers reachable within this area. This is initially zero and is calculated in each SPF pass.

ospfAreaLsaCount.name: ospfAreaLsaCount
ospfAreaLsaCount.description: The total number of link state advertisements in this area's link state database, excluding AS-external LSAs.

ospfAreaLsaCksumSum.name: ospfAreaLsaCksumSum
ospfAreaLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit sum of the link state advertisements' LS checksums contained in this area's link state database. This sum excludes external (LS type-5) link state advertisements. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in a router's link state database, and to compare the link state database of two routers. The value should be treated as unsigned when comparing two sums of checksums.

ospfAreaSummary.name: ospfAreaSummary
ospfAreaSummary.description: The variable ospfAreaSummary controls the import of summary LSAs into stub and NSSA areas. It has no effect on other areas. If it is noAreaSummary, the router will not originate summary LSAs into the stub or NSSA area. It will rely entirely on its default route. If it is sendAreaSummary, the router will both summarize and propagate summary LSAs.

ospfAreaStatus.name: ospfAreaStatus
ospfAreaStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfAreaNssaTranslatorRole.name: ospfAreaNssaTranslatorRole
ospfAreaNssaTranslatorRole.description: Indicates an NSSA border router's ability to perform NSSA translation of type-7 LSAs into type-5 LSAs.

ospfAreaNssaTranslatorState.name: ospfAreaNssaTranslatorState
ospfAreaNssaTranslatorState.description: Indicates if and how an NSSA border router is performing NSSA translation of type-7 LSAs into type-5 LSAs. When this object is set to enabled, the NSSA Border router's OspfAreaNssaExtTranslatorRole has been set to always. When this object is set to elected, a candidate NSSA Border router is Translating type-7 LSAs into type-5. When this object is set to disabled, a candidate NSSA border router is NOT translating type-7 LSAs into type-5.

ospfAreaNssaTranslatorStabilityInterval.name: ospfAreaNssaTranslatorStabilityInterval
ospfAreaNssaTranslatorStabilityInterval.description: The number of seconds after an elected translator determines its services are no longer required, that it should continue to perform its translation duties.

ospfAreaNssaTranslatorEvents.name: ospfAreaNssaTranslatorEvents
ospfAreaNssaTranslatorEvents.description: Indicates the number of translator state changes that have occurred since the last boot-up. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfStubAreaTable.name: ospfStubAreaTable
ospfStubAreaTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2, Area Parameters
ospfStubAreaTable.description: The set of metrics that will be advertised by a default Area Border Router into a stub area.

ospfStubAreaEntry.name: ospfStubAreaEntry
ospfStubAreaEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2, Area Parameters
ospfStubAreaEntry.description: The metric for a given Type of Service that will be advertised by a default Area Border Router into a stub area. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfStubAreaId.name: ospfStubAreaId
ospfStubAreaId.description: The 32-bit identifier for the stub area. On creation, this can be derived from the instance.

ospfStubTOS.name: ospfStubTOS
ospfStubTOS.description: The Type of Service associated with the metric. On creation, this can be derived from the instance.

ospfStubMetric.name: ospfStubMetric
ospfStubMetric.description: The metric value applied at the indicated Type of Service. By default, this equals the least metric at the Type of Service among the interfaces to other areas.

ospfStubStatus.name: ospfStubStatus
ospfStubStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfStubMetricType.name: ospfStubMetricType
ospfStubMetricType.description: This variable displays the type of metric advertised as a default route.

ospfLsdbTable.name: ospfLsdbTable
ospfLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
ospfLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's link state database (LSDB). The LSDB contains the link state advertisements from throughout the areas that the device is attached to.

ospfLsdbAreaId.name: ospfLsdbAreaId
ospfLsdbAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfLsdbAreaId.description: The 32-bit identifier of the area from which the LSA was received.

ospfLsdbType.name: ospfLsdbType
ospfLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
ospfLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format. Note: External link state advertisements are permitted for backward compatibility, but should be displayed in the ospfAsLsdbTable rather than here.

ospfLsdbLsid.name: ospfLsdbLsid
ospfLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
ospfLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

ospfLsdbRouterId.name: ospfLsdbRouterId
ospfLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
ospfLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

ospfLsdbSequence.name: ospfLsdbSequence
ospfLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
ospfLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate Link State Advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

ospfLsdbAge.name: ospfLsdbAge
ospfLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

ospfLsdbChecksum.name: ospfLsdbChecksum
ospfLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

ospfLsdbAdvertisement.name: ospfLsdbAdvertisement
ospfLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
ospfLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.

ospfAreaRangeTable.name: ospfAreaRangeTable
ospfAreaRangeTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaRangeTable.description: The Address Range Table acts as an adjunct to the Area Table. It describes those Address Range Summaries that are configured to be propagated from an Area to reduce the amount of information about it that is known beyond its borders. It contains a set of IP address ranges specified by an IP address/IP network mask pair. For example, class B address range of X.X.X.X with a network mask of 255.255.0.0 includes all IP addresses from X.X.0.0 to X.X.255.255. Note that this table is obsoleted and is replaced by the Area Aggregate Table.

ospfAreaRangeEntry.name: ospfAreaRangeEntry
ospfAreaRangeEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaRangeEntry.description: A single area address range. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfAreaRangeAreaId.name: ospfAreaRangeAreaId
ospfAreaRangeAreaId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaRangeAreaId.description: The area that the address range is to be found within.

ospfAreaRangeNet.name: ospfAreaRangeNet
ospfAreaRangeNet.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaRangeNet.description: The IP address of the net or subnet indicated by the range.

ospfAreaRangeMask.name: ospfAreaRangeMask
ospfAreaRangeMask.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaRangeMask.description: The subnet mask that pertains to the net or subnet.

ospfAreaRangeStatus.name: ospfAreaRangeStatus
ospfAreaRangeStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfAreaRangeEffect.name: ospfAreaRangeEffect
ospfAreaRangeEffect.description: Subnets subsumed by ranges either trigger the advertisement of the indicated summary (advertiseMatching) or result in the subnet's not being advertised at all outside the area.

ospfHostTable.name: ospfHostTable
ospfHostTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters
ospfHostTable.description: The Host/Metric Table indicates what hosts are directly attached to the router, what metrics and types of service should be advertised for them, and what areas they are found within.

ospfHostEntry.name: ospfHostEntry
ospfHostEntry.description: A metric to be advertised, for a given type of service, when a given host is reachable. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfHostIpAddress.name: ospfHostIpAddress
ospfHostIpAddress.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters
ospfHostIpAddress.description: The IP address of the host.

ospfHostTOS.name: ospfHostTOS
ospfHostTOS.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters
ospfHostTOS.description: The Type of Service of the route being configured.

ospfHostMetric.name: ospfHostMetric
ospfHostMetric.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host route parameters

ospfHostStatus.name: ospfHostStatus
ospfHostStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfHostAreaID.name: ospfHostAreaID
ospfHostAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host parameters
ospfHostAreaID.description: The OSPF area to which the host belongs. Deprecated by ospfHostCfgAreaID.

ospfHostCfgAreaID.name: ospfHostCfgAreaID
ospfHostCfgAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.7 Host parameters
ospfHostCfgAreaID.description: To configure the OSPF area to which the host belongs.

ospfIfTable.name: ospfIfTable
ospfIfTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
ospfIfTable.description: The OSPF Interface Table describes the interfaces from the viewpoint of OSPF. It augments the ipAddrTable with OSPF specific information.

ospfIfEntry.name: ospfIfEntry
ospfIfEntry.description: The OSPF interface entry describes one interface from the viewpoint of OSPF. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfIfIpAddress.name: ospfIfIpAddress
ospfIfIpAddress.description: The IP address of this OSPF interface.

ospfAddressLessIf.name: ospfAddressLessIf
ospfAddressLessIf.description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of addressed and addressless interfaces; this variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with IP addresses and the corresponding value of ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address.

ospfIfAreaId.name: ospfIfAreaId
ospfIfAreaId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the area to which the interface connects. Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.

ospfIfType.name: ospfIfType
ospfIfType.description: The OSPF interface type. By way of a default, this field may be intuited from the corresponding value of ifType. Broadcast LANs, such as Ethernet and IEEE 802.5, take the value 'broadcast', X.25 and similar technologies take the value 'nbma', and links that are definitively point to point take the value 'pointToPoint'.

ospfIfAdminStat.name: ospfIfAdminStat
ospfIfAdminStat.description: The OSPF interface's administrative status. The value formed on the interface, and the interface will be advertised as an internal route to some area. The value 'disabled' denotes that the interface is external to OSPF.

ospfIfRtrPriority.name: ospfIfRtrPriority
ospfIfRtrPriority.description: The priority of this interface. Used in multi-access networks, this field is used in the designated router election algorithm. The value 0 signifies that the router is not eligible to become the designated router on this particular network. In the event of a tie in this value, routers will use their Router ID as a tie breaker.

ospfIfTransitDelay.name: ospfIfTransitDelay
ospfIfTransitDelay.description: The estimated number of seconds it takes to transmit a link state update packet over this interface. Note that the minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

ospfIfRetransInterval.name: ospfIfRetransInterval
ospfIfRetransInterval.description: The number of seconds between link state advertisement retransmissions, for adjacencies belonging to this interface. This value is also used when retransmitting database description and Link State request packets. Note that minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

ospfIfHelloInterval.name: ospfIfHelloInterval
ospfIfHelloInterval.description: The length of time, in seconds, between the Hello packets that the router sends on the interface. This value must be the same for all routers attached to a common network.

ospfIfRtrDeadInterval.name: ospfIfRtrDeadInterval
ospfIfRtrDeadInterval.description: The number of seconds that a router's Hello packets have not been seen before its neighbors declare the router down. This should be some multiple of the Hello interval. This value must be the same for all routers attached to a common network.

ospfIfPollInterval.name: ospfIfPollInterval
ospfIfPollInterval.description: The larger time interval, in seconds, between the Hello packets sent to an inactive non-broadcast multi-access neighbor.

ospfIfDesignatedRouter.name: ospfIfDesignatedRouter
ospfIfDesignatedRouter.description: The IP address of the designated router.

ospfIfBackupDesignatedRouter.name: ospfIfBackupDesignatedRouter
ospfIfBackupDesignatedRouter.description: The IP address of the backup designated router.

ospfIfEvents.name: ospfIfEvents
ospfIfEvents.description: The number of times this OSPF interface has changed its state or an error has occurred. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfIfAuthKey.name: ospfIfAuthKey
ospfIfAuthKey.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 9 The Interface Data Structure
ospfIfAuthKey.description: The cleartext password used as an OSPF authentication key when simplePassword security is enabled. This object does not access any OSPF cryptogaphic (e.g., MD5) authentication key under any circumstance. If the key length is shorter than 8 octets, the agent will left adjust and zero fill to 8 octets. Unauthenticated interfaces need no authentication key, and simple password authentication cannot use a key of more than 8 octets. Note that the use of simplePassword authentication is NOT recommended when there is concern regarding attack upon the OSPF system. SimplePassword authentication is only sufficient to protect against accidental misconfigurations because it re-uses cleartext passwords [RFC1704]. When read, ospfIfAuthKey always returns an octet string of length zero.

ospfIfStatus.name: ospfIfStatus
ospfIfStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfIfMulticastForwarding.name: ospfIfMulticastForwarding
ospfIfMulticastForwarding.description: The way multicasts should be forwarded on this interface: not forwarded, forwarded as data link multicasts, or forwarded as data link unicasts. Data link multicasting is not meaningful on point-to-point and NBMA interfaces, and setting ospfMulticastForwarding to 0 effectively disables all multicast forwarding.

ospfIfDemand.name: ospfIfDemand
ospfIfDemand.description: Indicates whether Demand OSPF procedures (hello suppression to FULL neighbors and setting the DoNotAge flag on propagated LSAs) should be performed on this interface.

ospfIfAuthType.name: ospfIfAuthType
ospfIfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for an interface. Note that this object can be used to engage in significant attacks against an OSPF router.

ospfIfLsaCount.name: ospfIfLsaCount
ospfIfLsaCount.description: The total number of link-local link state advertisements in this interface's link-local link state database.

ospfIfLsaCksumSum.name: ospfIfLsaCksumSum
ospfIfLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the Link State Advertisements' LS checksums contained in this interface's link-local link state database. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in the interface's link state database and to compare the interface link state database of routers attached to the same subnet.

ospfIfDesignatedRouterId.name: ospfIfDesignatedRouterId
ospfIfDesignatedRouterId.description: The Router ID of the designated router.

ospfIfBackupDesignatedRouterId.name: ospfIfBackupDesignatedRouterId
ospfIfBackupDesignatedRouterId.description: The Router ID of the backup designated router.

ospfIfMetricTable.name: ospfIfMetricTable
ospfIfMetricTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
ospfIfMetricTable.description: The Metric Table describes the metrics to be advertised for a specified interface at the various types of service. As such, this table is an adjunct of the OSPF Interface Table. Types of service, as defined by RFC 791, have the ability to request low delay, high bandwidth, or reliable linkage. For the purposes of this specification, the measure of bandwidth: Metric = referenceBandwidth / ifSpeed is the default value. The default reference bandwidth is 10^8. For multiple link interfaces, note that ifSpeed is the sum of the individual link speeds. This yields a number having the following typical values: Network Type/bit rate Metric >= 100 MBPS 1 Ethernet/802.3 10 E1 48 T1 (ESF) 65 64 KBPS 1562 56 KBPS 1785 19.2 KBPS 5208 9.6 KBPS 10416 Routes that are not specified use the default (TOS 0) metric. Note that the default reference bandwidth can be configured using the general group object ospfReferenceBandwidth.

ospfIfMetricEntry.name: ospfIfMetricEntry
ospfIfMetricEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Router interface parameters
ospfIfMetricEntry.description: A particular TOS metric for a non-virtual interface identified by the interface index. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfIfMetricIpAddress.name: ospfIfMetricIpAddress
ospfIfMetricIpAddress.description: The IP address of this OSPF interface. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

ospfIfMetricAddressLessIf.name: ospfIfMetricAddressLessIf
ospfIfMetricAddressLessIf.description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of addressed and addressless interfaces; this variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with IP addresses and the value of ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

ospfIfMetricTOS.name: ospfIfMetricTOS
ospfIfMetricTOS.description: The Type of Service metric being referenced. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

ospfIfMetricValue.name: ospfIfMetricValue
ospfIfMetricValue.description: The metric of using this Type of Service on this interface. The default value of the TOS 0 metric is 10^8 / ifSpeed.

ospfIfMetricStatus.name: ospfIfMetricStatus
ospfIfMetricStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfVirtIfTable.name: ospfVirtIfTable
ospfVirtIfTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.4 Virtual link parameters
ospfVirtIfTable.description: Information about this router's virtual interfaces that the OSPF Process is configured to carry on.

ospfVirtIfEntry.name: ospfVirtIfEntry
ospfVirtIfEntry.description: Information about a single virtual interface. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfVirtIfAreaId.name: ospfVirtIfAreaId
ospfVirtIfAreaId.description: The transit area that the virtual link traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0.

ospfVirtIfNeighbor.name: ospfVirtIfNeighbor
ospfVirtIfNeighbor.description: The Router ID of the virtual neighbor.

ospfVirtIfTransitDelay.name: ospfVirtIfTransitDelay
ospfVirtIfTransitDelay.description: The estimated number of seconds it takes to transmit a Link State update packet over this interface. Note that the minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

ospfVirtIfRetransInterval.name: ospfVirtIfRetransInterval
ospfVirtIfRetransInterval.description: The number of seconds between link state avertisement retransmissions, for adjacencies belonging to this interface. This value is also used when retransmitting database description and Link State request packets. This value should be well over the expected round-trip time. Note that the minimal value SHOULD be 1 second.

ospfVirtIfHelloInterval.name: ospfVirtIfHelloInterval
ospfVirtIfHelloInterval.description: The length of time, in seconds, between the Hello packets that the router sends on the interface. This value must be the same for the virtual neighbor.

ospfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval.name: ospfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval
ospfVirtIfRtrDeadInterval.description: The number of seconds that a router's Hello packets have not been seen before its neighbors declare the router down. This should be some multiple of the Hello interval. This value must be the same for the virtual neighbor.

ospfVirtIfEvents.name: ospfVirtIfEvents
ospfVirtIfEvents.description: The number of state changes or error events on this virtual link. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfVirtIfAuthKey.name: ospfVirtIfAuthKey
ospfVirtIfAuthKey.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 9 The Interface Data Structure
ospfVirtIfAuthKey.description: The cleartext password used as an OSPF authentication key when simplePassword security is enabled. This object does not access any OSPF cryptogaphic (e.g., MD5) authentication key under any circumstance. If the key length is shorter than 8 octets, the agent will left adjust and zero fill to 8 octets. Unauthenticated interfaces need no authentication key, and simple password authentication cannot use a key of more than 8 octets. Note that the use of simplePassword authentication is NOT recommended when there is concern regarding attack upon the OSPF system. SimplePassword authentication is only sufficient to protect against accidental misconfigurations because it re-uses cleartext passwords. [RFC1704] When read, ospfIfAuthKey always returns an octet string of length zero.

ospfVirtIfStatus.name: ospfVirtIfStatus
ospfVirtIfStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfVirtIfAuthType.name: ospfVirtIfAuthType
ospfVirtIfAuthType.description: The authentication type specified for a virtual interface. Note that this object can be used to engage in significant attacks against an OSPF router.

ospfVirtIfLsaCount.name: ospfVirtIfLsaCount
ospfVirtIfLsaCount.description: The total number of link-local link state advertisements in this virtual interface's link-local link state database.

ospfVirtIfLsaCksumSum.name: ospfVirtIfLsaCksumSum
ospfVirtIfLsaCksumSum.description: The 32-bit unsigned sum of the link state advertisements' LS checksums contained in this virtual interface's link-local link state database. The sum can be used to determine if there has been a change in the virtual interface's link state database, and to compare the virtual interface link state database of the virtual neighbors.

ospfNbrTable.name: ospfNbrTable
ospfNbrTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 10 The Neighbor Data Structure
ospfNbrTable.description: A table describing all non-virtual neighbors in the locality of the OSPF router.

ospfNbrEntry.name: ospfNbrEntry
ospfNbrEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 10 The Neighbor Data Structure
ospfNbrEntry.description: The information regarding a single neighbor. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfNbrIpAddr.name: ospfNbrIpAddr
ospfNbrIpAddr.description: The IP address this neighbor is using in its IP source address. Note that, on addressless links, this will not be 0.0.0.0 but the address of another of the neighbor's interfaces.

ospfNbrAddressLessIndex.name: ospfNbrAddressLessIndex
ospfNbrAddressLessIndex.description: On an interface having an IP address, zero. On addressless interfaces, the corresponding value of ifIndex in the Internet Standard MIB. On row creation, this can be derived from the instance.

ospfNbrRtrId.name: ospfNbrRtrId
ospfNbrRtrId.description: A 32-bit integer (represented as a type IpAddress) uniquely identifying the neighboring router in the Autonomous System.

ospfNbrOptions.name: ospfNbrOptions
ospfNbrOptions.description: A bit mask corresponding to the neighbor's options field. Bit 0, if set, indicates that the system will operate on Type of Service metrics other than TOS 0. If zero, the neighbor will ignore all metrics except the TOS 0 metric. Bit 1, if set, indicates that the associated area accepts and operates on external information; if zero, it is a stub area. Bit 2, if set, indicates that the system is capable of routing IP multicast datagrams, that is that it implements the multicast extensions to OSPF. Bit 3, if set, indicates that the associated area is an NSSA. These areas are capable of carrying type-7 external advertisements, which are translated into type-5 external advertisements at NSSA borders.

ospfNbrPriority.name: ospfNbrPriority
ospfNbrPriority.description: The priority of this neighbor in the designated router election algorithm. The value 0 signifies that the neighbor is not eligible to become the designated router on this particular network.

ospfNbrState.name: ospfNbrState
ospfNbrState.description: The state of the relationship with this neighbor.

ospfNbrEvents.name: ospfNbrEvents
ospfNbrEvents.description: The number of times this neighbor relationship has changed state or an error has occurred. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfNbrLsRetransQLen.name: ospfNbrLsRetransQLen
ospfNbrLsRetransQLen.description: The current length of the retransmission queue.

ospfNbmaNbrStatus.name: ospfNbmaNbrStatus
ospfNbmaNbrStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfNbmaNbrPermanence.name: ospfNbmaNbrPermanence
ospfNbmaNbrPermanence.description: This variable displays the status of the entry; 'dynamic' and 'permanent' refer to how the neighbor became known.

ospfNbrHelloSuppressed.name: ospfNbrHelloSuppressed
ospfNbrHelloSuppressed.description: Indicates whether Hellos are being suppressed to the neighbor.

ospfNbrRestartHelperStatus.name: ospfNbrRestartHelperStatus
ospfNbrRestartHelperStatus.description: Indicates whether the router is acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

ospfNbrRestartHelperAge.name: ospfNbrRestartHelperAge
ospfNbrRestartHelperAge.description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart interval, if the router is acting as a restart helper for the neighbor.

ospfNbrRestartHelperExitReason.name: ospfNbrRestartHelperExitReason
ospfNbrRestartHelperExitReason.description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

ospfVirtNbrTable.name: ospfVirtNbrTable
ospfVirtNbrTable.description: This table describes all virtual neighbors. Since virtual links are configured in the Virtual Interface Table, this table is read-only.

ospfVirtNbrRtrId.name: ospfVirtNbrRtrId
ospfVirtNbrRtrId.description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the neighboring router in the Autonomous System.

ospfVirtNbrIpAddr.name: ospfVirtNbrIpAddr
ospfVirtNbrIpAddr.description: The IP address this virtual neighbor is using.

ospfVirtNbrOptions.name: ospfVirtNbrOptions
ospfVirtNbrOptions.description: A bit mask corresponding to the neighbor's options field. Bit 1, if set, indicates that the system will operate on Type of Service metrics other than TOS 0. If zero, the neighbor will ignore all metrics except the TOS 0 metric. Bit 2, if set, indicates that the system is network multicast capable, i.e., that it implements OSPF multicast routing.

ospfVirtNbrState.name: ospfVirtNbrState
ospfVirtNbrState.description: The state of the virtual neighbor relationship.

ospfVirtNbrEvents.name: ospfVirtNbrEvents
ospfVirtNbrEvents.description: The number of times this virtual link has changed its state or an error has occurred. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ospfDiscontinuityTime.

ospfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen.name: ospfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen
ospfVirtNbrLsRetransQLen.description: The current length of the retransmission queue.

ospfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed.name: ospfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed
ospfVirtNbrHelloSuppressed.description: Indicates whether Hellos are being suppressed to the neighbor.

ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus.name: ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus
ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus.description: Indicates whether the router is acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge.name: ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge
ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge.description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart interval, if the router is acting as a restart helper for the neighbor.

ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason.name: ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason
ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason.description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at acting as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.

ospfExtLsdbTable.name: ospfExtLsdbTable
ospfExtLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
ospfExtLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's external LSA link state database. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only external link state advertisements. The purpose is to allow external LSAs to be displayed once for the router rather than once in each non-stub area. Note that external LSAs are also in the AS-scope link state database.

ospfExtLsdbType.name: ospfExtLsdbType
ospfExtLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
ospfExtLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

ospfExtLsdbLsid.name: ospfExtLsdbLsid
ospfExtLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
ospfExtLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

ospfExtLsdbRouterId.name: ospfExtLsdbRouterId
ospfExtLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
ospfExtLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

ospfExtLsdbSequence.name: ospfExtLsdbSequence
ospfExtLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
ospfExtLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

ospfExtLsdbAge.name: ospfExtLsdbAge
ospfExtLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

ospfExtLsdbChecksum.name: ospfExtLsdbChecksum
ospfExtLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

ospfExtLsdbAdvertisement.name: ospfExtLsdbAdvertisement
ospfExtLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
ospfExtLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header.

ospfAreaAggregateTable.name: ospfAreaAggregateTable
ospfAreaAggregateTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaAggregateTable.description: The Area Aggregate Table acts as an adjunct to the Area Table. It describes those address aggregates that are configured to be propagated from an area. Its purpose is to reduce the amount of information that is known beyond an Area's borders. It contains a set of IP address ranges specified by an IP address/IP network mask pair. For example, a class B address range of X.X.X.X with a network mask of 255.255.0.0 includes all IP addresses from X.X.0.0 to X.X.255.255. Note that if ranges are configured such that one range subsumes another range (e.g., 10.0.0.0 mask 255.0.0.0 and 10.1.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0), the most specific match is the preferred one.

ospfAreaAggregateEntry.name: ospfAreaAggregateEntry
ospfAreaAggregateEntry.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaAggregateEntry.description: A single area aggregate entry. Information in this table is persistent and when this object is written the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

ospfAreaAggregateAreaID.name: ospfAreaAggregateAreaID
ospfAreaAggregateAreaID.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaAggregateAreaID.description: The area within which the address aggregate is to be found.

ospfAreaAggregateLsdbType.name: ospfAreaAggregateLsdbType
ospfAreaAggregateLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
ospfAreaAggregateLsdbType.description: The type of the address aggregate. This field specifies the Lsdb type that this address aggregate applies to.

ospfAreaAggregateNet.name: ospfAreaAggregateNet
ospfAreaAggregateNet.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaAggregateNet.description: The IP address of the net or subnet indicated by the range.

ospfAreaAggregateMask.name: ospfAreaAggregateMask
ospfAreaAggregateMask.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.2 Area parameters
ospfAreaAggregateMask.description: The subnet mask that pertains to the net or subnet.

ospfAreaAggregateStatus.name: ospfAreaAggregateStatus
ospfAreaAggregateStatus.description: This object permits management of the table by facilitating actions such as row creation, construction, and destruction. The value of this object has no effect on whether other objects in this conceptual row can be modified.

ospfAreaAggregateEffect.name: ospfAreaAggregateEffect
ospfAreaAggregateEffect.description: Subnets subsumed by ranges either trigger the advertisement of the indicated aggregate (advertiseMatching) or result in the subnet's not being advertised at all outside the area.

ospfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag.name: ospfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag
ospfAreaAggregateExtRouteTag.description: External route tag to be included in NSSA (type-7) LSAs.

ospfLocalLsdbTable.name: ospfLocalLsdbTable
ospfLocalLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements and The OSPF Opaque LSA Option
ospfLocalLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's link-local link state database for non-virtual links. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only link-local Link State Advertisements for non-virtual links. The purpose is to allow link-local LSAs to be displayed for each non-virtual interface. This table is implemented to support type-9 LSAs that are defined in 'The OSPF Opaque LSA Option'.

ospfLocalLsdbIpAddress.name: ospfLocalLsdbIpAddress
ospfLocalLsdbIpAddress.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
ospfLocalLsdbIpAddress.description: The IP address of the interface from which the LSA was received if the interface is numbered.

ospfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf.name: ospfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf
ospfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
ospfLocalLsdbAddressLessIf.description: The interface index of the interface from which the LSA was received if the interface is unnumbered.

ospfLocalLsdbType.name: ospfLocalLsdbType
ospfLocalLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
ospfLocalLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

ospfLocalLsdbLsid.name: ospfLocalLsdbLsid
ospfLocalLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
ospfLocalLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing a 32-bit identifier in IP address format; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

ospfLocalLsdbRouterId.name: ospfLocalLsdbRouterId
ospfLocalLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
ospfLocalLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

ospfLocalLsdbSequence.name: ospfLocalLsdbSequence
ospfLocalLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
ospfLocalLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

ospfLocalLsdbAge.name: ospfLocalLsdbAge
ospfLocalLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

ospfLocalLsdbChecksum.name: ospfLocalLsdbChecksum
ospfLocalLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

ospfLocalLsdbAdvertisement.name: ospfLocalLsdbAdvertisement
ospfLocalLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
ospfLocalLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbTable.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbTable
ospfVirtLocalLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements and The OSPF Opaque LSA Option
ospfVirtLocalLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's link-local link state database for virtual links. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only link-local Link State Advertisements for virtual links. The purpose is to allow link-local LSAs to be displayed for each virtual interface. This table is implemented to support type-9 LSAs that are defined in 'The OSPF Opaque LSA Option'.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea
ospfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
ospfVirtLocalLsdbTransitArea.description: The transit area that the virtual link traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor
ospfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.3 Interface parameters
ospfVirtLocalLsdbNeighbor.description: The Router ID of the virtual neighbor.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbType.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbType
ospfVirtLocalLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
ospfVirtLocalLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbLsid.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbLsid
ospfVirtLocalLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
ospfVirtLocalLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing a 32-bit identifier in IP address format; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId
ospfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
ospfVirtLocalLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbSequence.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbSequence
ospfVirtLocalLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
ospfVirtLocalLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbAge.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbAge
ospfVirtLocalLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbChecksum.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbChecksum
ospfVirtLocalLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement
ospfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.
ospfVirtLocalLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header.

ospfAsLsdbTable.name: ospfAsLsdbTable
ospfAsLsdbTable.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements
ospfAsLsdbTable.description: The OSPF Process's AS-scope LSA link state database. The database contains the AS-scope Link State Advertisements from throughout the areas that the device is attached to. This table is identical to the OSPF LSDB Table in format, but contains only AS-scope Link State Advertisements. The purpose is to allow AS-scope LSAs to be displayed once for the router rather than once in each non-stub area.

ospfAsLsdbType.name: ospfAsLsdbType
ospfAsLsdbType.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix A.4.1 The Link State Advertisement header
ospfAsLsdbType.description: The type of the link state advertisement. Each link state type has a separate advertisement format.

ospfAsLsdbLsid.name: ospfAsLsdbLsid
ospfAsLsdbLsid.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.4 Link State ID
ospfAsLsdbLsid.description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field containing either a Router ID or an IP address; it identifies the piece of the routing domain that is being described by the advertisement.

ospfAsLsdbRouterId.name: ospfAsLsdbRouterId
ospfAsLsdbRouterId.reference: OSPF Version 2, Appendix C.1 Global parameters
ospfAsLsdbRouterId.description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the originating router in the Autonomous System.

ospfAsLsdbSequence.name: ospfAsLsdbSequence
ospfAsLsdbSequence.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12.1.6 LS sequence number
ospfAsLsdbSequence.description: The sequence number field is a signed 32-bit integer. It starts with the value '80000001'h, or -'7FFFFFFF'h, and increments until '7FFFFFFF'h. Thus, a typical sequence number will be very negative. It is used to detect old and duplicate link state advertisements. The space of sequence numbers is linearly ordered. The larger the sequence number, the more recent the advertisement.

ospfAsLsdbAge.name: ospfAsLsdbAge
ospfAsLsdbAge.description: This field is the age of the link state advertisement in seconds.

ospfAsLsdbChecksum.name: ospfAsLsdbChecksum
ospfAsLsdbChecksum.description: This field is the checksum of the complete contents of the advertisement, excepting the age field. The age field is excepted so that an advertisement's age can be incremented without updating the checksum. The checksum used is the same that is used for ISO connectionless datagrams; it is commonly referred to as the Fletcher checksum.

ospfAsLsdbAdvertisement.name: ospfAsLsdbAdvertisement
ospfAsLsdbAdvertisement.reference: OSPF Version 2, Section 12 Link State Advertisements. Note that for variable length LSAs, SNMP agents may not be able to return the largest string size.
ospfAsLsdbAdvertisement.description: The entire link state advertisement, including its header.

ospfAreaLsaCountTable.name: ospfAreaLsaCountTable
ospfAreaLsaCountTable.description: This table maintains per-area, per-LSA-type counters

ospfAreaLsaCountEntry.name: ospfAreaLsaCountEntry
ospfAreaLsaCountEntry.description: An entry with a number of link advertisements of a given type for a given area.

ospfAreaLsaCountNumber.name: ospfAreaLsaCountNumber
ospfAreaLsaCountNumber.description: Number of LSAs of a given type for a given area.

ospfCompliance.name: ospfCompliance
ospfCompliance.description: The compliance statement for OSPF systems conforming to RFC 1850.

ospfBasicGroup.name: ospfBasicGroup
ospfBasicGroup.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage global OSPF parameters. This object group conforms to RFC 1850.

ospfAreaGroup.name: ospfAreaGroup
ospfAreaGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems supporting areas per RFC 1850.

ospfStubAreaGroup.name: ospfStubAreaGroup
ospfStubAreaGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems supporting stub areas.

ospfLsdbGroup.name: ospfLsdbGroup
ospfLsdbGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that display their link state database.

ospfAreaRangeGroup.name: ospfAreaRangeGroup
ospfAreaRangeGroup.description: These objects are used for non-CIDR OSPF systems that support multiple areas. This object group is obsolete.

ospfHostGroup.name: ospfHostGroup
ospfHostGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that support attached hosts.

ospfIfGroup.name: ospfIfGroup
ospfIfGroup.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF interfaces. This object group conforms to RFC 1850.

ospfIfMetricGroup.name: ospfIfMetricGroup
ospfIfMetricGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems for supporting interface metrics.

ospfVirtIfGroup.name: ospfVirtIfGroup
ospfVirtIfGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems for supporting virtual interfaces. This object group conforms to RFC 1850.

ospfNbrGroup.name: ospfNbrGroup
ospfNbrGroup.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF neighbors. This object group conforms to RFC 1850.

ospfVirtNbrGroup.name: ospfVirtNbrGroup
ospfVirtNbrGroup.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF virtual neighbors. This object group conforms to RFC 1850.

ospfExtLsdbGroup.name: ospfExtLsdbGroup
ospfExtLsdbGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that display their link state database. This object group conforms to RFC 1850. This object group is replaced by the ospfAsLsdbGroup in order to support any AS-scope LSA type in a single table.

ospfAreaAggregateGroup.name: ospfAreaAggregateGroup
ospfAreaAggregateGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems to support network prefix aggregation across areas.

ospfLocalLsdbGroup.name: ospfLocalLsdbGroup
ospfLocalLsdbGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that display their link-local link state databases for non-virtual links.

ospfVirtLocalLsdbGroup.name: ospfVirtLocalLsdbGroup
ospfVirtLocalLsdbGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that display their link-local link state databases for virtual links.

ospfAsLsdbGroup.name: ospfAsLsdbGroup
ospfAsLsdbGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that display their AS-scope link state database.

ospfBasicGroup2.name: ospfBasicGroup2
ospfBasicGroup2.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF global parameters.

ospfAreaGroup2.name: ospfAreaGroup2
ospfAreaGroup2.description: These objects are used by OSPF systems to support areas.

ospfIfGroup2.name: ospfIfGroup2
ospfIfGroup2.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF interfaces.

ospfVirtIfGroup2.name: ospfVirtIfGroup2
ospfVirtIfGroup2.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF virtual interfaces.

ospfNbrGroup2.name: ospfNbrGroup2
ospfNbrGroup2.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF neighbors.

ospfVirtNbrGroup2.name: ospfVirtNbrGroup2
ospfVirtNbrGroup2.description: These objects are used to monitor/manage OSPF virtual neighbors.

ospfAreaAggregateGroup2.name: ospfAreaAggregateGroup2
ospfAreaAggregateGroup2.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems to support network prefix aggregation across areas.

ospfAreaLsaCountGroup.name: ospfAreaLsaCountGroup
ospfAreaLsaCountGroup.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that display per-area, per-LSA-type counters.

ospfHostGroup2.name: ospfHostGroup2
ospfHostGroup2.description: These objects are used for OSPF systems that support attached hosts.

ospfObsoleteGroup.name: ospfObsoleteGroup
ospfObsoleteGroup.description: These objects are obsolete and are no longer required for OSPF systems. They are placed into this group for SMI conformance.
